1. Soak rice and urad dal for 4-5 hours.

 2. Grind them into a smooth batter.

 3. Let the batter ferment overnight.

 4. Heat the Idli steamer and grease the idli molds.

 5. Pour the batter into the molds and steam for 10-15 minutes.

 6. Serve with sambar and chutney.

1. Soak chickpeas overnight and boil them.

 2. In a pan, heat oil and add cumin seeds, bay leaves, and onions.

 3. Add chopped tomatoes, ginger-garlic paste, and cook till soft.

 4. Add spices (turmeric, garam masala, coriander powder, etc.) and mix well.

 5. Add boiled chickpeas and cook for 10-15 minutes.

 6. Garnish with coriander leaves and serve with bhature or rice.

1. Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds.

 2. Add chopped onions and sauté until golden.

 3. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until soft.

 4. Add rice, water, and salt. Stir well.

 5. Cover and cook for 15-20 minutes on low heat.

 6. Garnish with coriander leaves and serve hot.

1. Heat milk in a pan and bring to a boil.

 2. Add rice and cook for 15-20 minutes on low heat.

 3. Add sugar and stir until it dissolves.

 4. Add cardamom powder and dry fruits, mix well.

 5. Cook for another 5-10 minutes.

 6. Serve hot or chilled.

1. Blanch spinach and puree it.

 2. Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds.

 3. Add onions and sauté until golden.

 4. Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté.

 5. Add the spinach puree, spices (turmeric, garam masala, etc.), and cook for 10 minutes.

 6. Add cubed paneer, cook for 5 minutes, and serve hot.

1. Mix flour, yeast, sugar, and salt in a bowl.

 2. Add warm water and knead into a dough.

 3. Let the dough rest for 1-2 hours to rise.

 4. Roll the dough into small balls and flatten them.

 5. Cook the naans on a hot griddle or tandoor.

 6. Brush with butter and serve hot.

1. Heat milk and bring it to a boil.

 2. Add lemon juice or vinegar to curdle the milk.

 3. Strain the curdled milk to separate the paneer.

 4. Press the paneer to remove excess water.

 5. Cube the paneer and use it in your recipe.

1. Mix yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, and spices to make the marinade.

 2. Coat the chicken (or vegetables) with the marinade and let it sit for 1-2 hours.

 3. Preheat the oven or tandoor.

 4. Skewer the chicken and cook until done.

 5. Serve with naan and chutney.

1. Soak basmati rice for 30 minutes.

 2. Heat oil in a pan, add whole spices, and sauté.

 3. Add onions and cook until golden.

 4. Add chopped vegetables, and cook for 5-7 minutes.

 5. Add rice, water, and spices, and cook until done.

 6. Garnish with fried onions and serve hot.

1. Mix rice flour, besan (gram flour), and spices in a bowl.

 2. Add water and make a smooth batter.

 3. Steam the batter in a greased pan for 15-20 minutes.

 4. Let it cool and cut into squares.

 5. Temper with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and green chilies.

 6. Serve with green chutney.

1. Soak 1 cup raw rice and 1/4 cup urad dal for 4-6 hours.
 2. Grind to a smooth batter with a bit of cooked rice.
 3. Add 1/2 tsp yeast and a pinch of sugar. Let it ferment overnight.
 4. Add salt and a little coconut milk for softness.
 5. Heat an appam pan, pour a ladle of batter, swirl and cook covered till edges are crisp.
 6. Serve hot with stew or chutney.

1. Rinse 1/2 cup toor dal and pressure cook until soft.
 2. Cook 1/2 cup rice separately and keep aside.
 3. In a pan, heat oil and sauté chopped onions, carrots, beans, peas for 5–7 mins.
 4. Add tamarind extract, salt, turmeric, and Bisibele Bath powder.
 5. Mix in the cooked dal and vegetables. Let it simmer.
 6. Add cooked rice and mix well. Adjust consistency with water.
 7. Temper mustard seeds, curry leaves, dry red chilies in ghee and pour over the bath.
 8. Serve hot with boondi or papad.

1. Finely chop 2 cups of cabbage and keep aside.
 2. Coarsely grind 1/2 cup grated coconut, 2 green chilies, 1/2 tsp cumin seeds, and 2 garlic cloves.
 3. Heat 2 tsp coconut oil in a pan, splutter mustard seeds and curry leaves.
 4. Add chopped onions (optional) and sauté till soft.
 5. Add the cabbage and the coconut mixture, mix well.
 6. Add salt and a splash of water, cover and cook on low flame till cabbage is soft.
 7. Stir occasionally to prevent burning.
 8. Once done, uncover and sauté for a minute. Serve hot with rice.

1. Dry roast 1/2 cup moong dal till aromatic, then rinse.
 2. Add 1/2 cup rice and 3 cups water to the dal, pressure cook for 4–5 whistles.
 3. In a small pan, heat ghee and fry 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1/2 tsp black pepper, grated ginger, and cashews.
 4. Add curry leaves and a pinch of asafoetida.
 5. Pour the tempering over the cooked pongal, add salt and mix well.
 6. Adjust consistency with hot water if needed.
 7. Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

1. Heat 2 tbsp ghee in a pan and roast 1/2 cup rava (semolina) until aromatic. Set aside.
 2. In another pan, boil 1.5 cups water with a pinch of saffron and 1/4 tsp cardamom powder.
 3. Slowly add the roasted rava to the boiling water while stirring to avoid lumps.
 4. Cook on low flame till rava absorbs all the water.
 5. Add 1/2 cup sugar and mix well till it melts.
 6. Stir in 1 tbsp ghee and cook until the mixture thickens.
 7. Fry cashews and raisins in ghee, then mix them into the kesaribath.
 8. Serve warm garnished with more ghee or dry fruits if desired.

1. Mix 1 cup rice flour, 1/4 cup grated coconut, and salt in a large bowl.
 2. Add water gradually and knead the dough until it’s smooth and pliable.
 3. Divide the dough into small balls, then roll each ball into a thin circle.
 4. Heat a tawa (griddle) and place the rolled dough on it. Cook on medium heat.
 5. Drizzle a little oil around the edges and cook both sides till golden brown and crispy.
 6. Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

1. Cook 1 cup rice and allow it to cool.
 2. In a pan, heat 2 tbsp oil and fry 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1/2 tsp cumin seeds, and 2 dried red chilies.
 3. Add a pinch of asafoetida and 10-12 curry leaves, then sauté for a minute.
 4. Stir in 1/4 cup chopped onions and sauté till translucent.
 5. Add 1/4 cup peanuts and fry for a few minutes.
 6. Add 2 tbsp lemon juice, salt, and turmeric powder. Mix well.
 7. Add the cooled rice and toss to coat evenly.
 8. Serve hot with a side of yogurt or pickle.

1. In a pan, heat 2 cups of water and bring it to a boil.
 2. Gradually add 1 cup of ragi flour, stirring constantly to prevent lumps.
 3. Reduce the heat to low and cook, stirring continuously, until the mixture thickens and pulls away from the sides of the pan.
 4. Once the mixture has thickened, remove it from heat and let it cool slightly.
 5. Wet your hands and shape the dough into balls (mudde).
 6. Serve the ragi mudde with sambar, curry, or a spicy chutney.

1. Soak 1 cup rice and 1/4 cup urad dal for 4-6 hours.
 2. Grind the soaked ingredients to a smooth batter, adding water as needed.
 3. Ferment the batter overnight in a warm place.
 4. Heat a tawa (griddle) and pour a ladle of batter to spread it in a circular shape.
 5. Drizzle oil around the edges and cook until crispy and golden brown.
 6. Flip and cook the other side for a minute.
 7. Serve hot with coconut chutney and sambar.

1. Boil and mash 2 medium potatoes.
 2. In a pan, heat oil, add mustard seeds, curry leaves, green chili, and ginger garlic paste.
 3. Add turmeric and mashed potatoes, mix well and let it cool.
 4. Shape into balls and dip in gram flour batter.
 5. Deep fry until golden brown.
 6. Toast pav with butter, apply green chutney and tamarind chutney.
 7. Place vada inside and serve hot with fried green chili.

1. Boil potatoes, peas, and cauliflower until soft.
 2. In a pan, heat butter and sauté onions until golden.
 3. Add chopped tomatoes, ginger garlic paste, and pav bhaji masala.
 4. Mash the boiled veggies and add them to the pan.
 5. Add water to adjust consistency and simmer for 10 minutes.
 6. Toast pav with butter.
 7. Serve hot bhaji with buttered pav, chopped onions, and lemon.

1. Prepare dough with maida, salt, and oil. Rest for 30 mins.
 2. For filling, cook mashed potatoes with peas, spices, and coriander.
 3. Divide dough, roll into ovals, cut in half, and shape into cones.
 4. Stuff the cones with filling and seal the edges.
 5. Deep fry on medium heat until golden and crisp.
 6. Serve hot with mint and tamarind chutneys.

1. Arrange crushed puris or papdi in a plate.
 2. Add boiled potatoes, chickpeas, and chopped onions.
 3. Drizzle yogurt, green chutney, and tamarind chutney.
 4. Sprinkle chaat masala, red chili powder, and cumin powder.
 5. Garnish with sev, coriander leaves, and pomegranate.
 6. Serve immediately before it gets soggy.

1. Boil and mash potatoes, and add finely chopped vegetables.
 2. Add bread crumbs, spices, and mix well.
 3. Shape into kebabs or patties.
 4. Shallow fry on a pan with oil until golden brown on both sides.
 5. Serve hot with mint chutney and lemon wedges.

1. In a bowl, mix puffed rice, chopped onions, tomatoes, and boiled potatoes.
 2. Add green chutney, tamarind chutney, and a dash of lemon juice.
 3. Sprinkle chaat masala and mix well.
 4. Add sev just before serving to keep it crunchy.
 5. Serve immediately as a quick snack.

1. Prepare a soft dough using whole wheat flour and let it rest.
 2. Cook spiced mashed potato filling or use paneer/chicken.
 3. Roll out roti and cook on a tawa, then spread egg if desired and cook.
 4. Place filling, chopped onions, sauces, and roll tightly.
 5. Toast lightly with butter and serve hot.

1. Boil and mash potatoes, add green chili, coriander, and spices.
 2. Shape into round tikkis and shallow fry until crispy.
 3. Optionally stuff with green peas mixture.
 4. Serve hot with chutneys or as part of a chaat with curd and masalas.

1. Prepare a dough and roll into rotis. Cook on a tawa.
 2. Beat eggs with salt and pour on the roti while cooking.
 3. Flip and cook both sides.
 4. Add onion slices, green chutney, ketchup, and roll tightly.
 5. Wrap in paper and serve hot.

1. Mix 1 cup semolina (sooji) and 1/4 cup all-purpose flour with water to form a stiff dough.
 2. Roll into small discs and deep-fry until puffed and crispy to make puris.
 3. Boil and mash 2 potatoes; mix with chopped onions, coriander, and spices.
 4. For the pani, blend mint, coriander, green chilies, tamarind, black salt, and water.
 5. Chill the spicy water (pani) before serving.
 6. Crack the top of each puri and fill with potato mixture and sweet chutney.
 7. Pour the spiced pani into the puris and serve immediately.

1. In a large bowl, combine yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, red chili powder, turmeric powder, garam masala, cumin powder, lemon juice, and salt to make the marinade.
 2. Add the chicken pieces to the marinade and coat them well. Cover the bowl and refrigerate for at least 1 hour (overnight for better flavor).
 3. Preheat the grill or oven to 200°C (400°F). If using a grill pan, heat it on medium-high.
 4. Thread the marinated chicken pieces onto skewers.
 5. Brush the chicken with a little oil and place it on the grill or in the oven.
 6. Grill for 20-25 minutes or until the chicken is fully cooked and slightly charred at the edges, turning occasionally for even grilling.
 7. Once done, remove the chicken from the skewers.
 8. Serve hot with naan or rice, and garnish with fresh coriander and lemon wedges.
 9. Enjoy your delicious Chicken Tikka!

1. In a large bowl, combine yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, red chili powder, turmeric powder, garam masala, cumin powder, and salt to make the marinade.
 2. Add the chicken pieces to the marinade and coat them well. Cover the bowl and refrigerate for at least 1 hour (overnight for better flavor).
 3. Preheat the grill or oven to 200°C (400°F). If using a grill pan, heat it on medium-high.
 4. Thread the marinated chicken pieces onto skewers.
 5. Brush the chicken with a little oil and place it on the grill or in the oven.
 6. Grill for 20-25 minutes or until the chicken is fully cooked and slightly charred at the edges, turning occasionally for even grilling.
 7. Once done, remove the chicken from the skewers.
 8. Prepare the rich butter sauce with tomatoes, cream, garlic, ginger, and spices.
 9. Add the grilled chicken pieces into the sauce and simmer until fully coated and heated through.
 10. Serve the butter chicken hot with naan or rice, garnished with fresh coriander.
 11. Enjoy your creamy and delicious Butter Chicken!

1. Start by grinding mutton (preferably boneless) along with onions, garlic, ginger, green chilies, and a handful of coriander leaves into a fine paste.
 2. Transfer the mixture to a large bowl and add garam masala, red chili powder, turmeric powder, cumin powder, and salt to taste.
 3. Add a little beaten yogurt to the mixture and knead it into a smooth dough.
 4. Divide the mixture into small portions and shape each portion into a round or oval kebab.
 5. Heat a non-stick pan or grill and brush with oil.
 6. Place the kebabs on the pan or grill, cooking them on medium heat for 8-10 minutes, turning occasionally until they are evenly browned and cooked through.
 7. Garnish the mutton kebabs with finely chopped onions, coriander, and a squeeze of lime juice.
 8. Serve hot with mint chutney and naan or rice.
 9. Enjoy your flavorful Mutton Kebabs!

1. Marinate 500g chicken strips with 1 cup yogurt, 1 tbsp lemon juice, 1 tbsp garlic paste, 1 tsp paprika, 1 tsp cumin, 1 tsp coriander, salt, and pepper.
 2. Let it rest for at least 1-2 hours or overnight for best results.
 3. Heat a pan or grill, drizzle a bit of oil, and cook the marinated chicken on medium heat until fully cooked and slightly charred.
 4. Warm pita bread or flatbreads on a pan or in the oven.
 5. Spread garlic sauce or tahini on the bread.
 6. Add cooked chicken strips, shredded lettuce, sliced onions, tomatoes, and cucumbers.
 7. Optionally, drizzle hot sauce or more garlic sauce on top.
 8. Roll the bread into a wrap or fold like a sandwich.
 9. Serve warm with fries or pickled vegetables.

1. Boil 4–6 eggs, peel them, and lightly score or prick them with a fork.
 2. Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan and lightly fry the boiled eggs until golden. Set aside.
 3. In the same pan, add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
 4. Add 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1–2 minutes until fragrant.
 5. Add 2 chopped tomatoes, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1 tsp coriander powder, and salt. Cook until oil separates.
 6. Add water as needed to make a curry base and bring it to a boil.
 7. Add the fried eggs and let them simmer in the curry for 5–10 minutes.
 8. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
 9. Serve hot with steamed rice or roti.

1. Clean and cut 500g of fish into pieces. Pat them dry with a paper towel.
 2. In a bowl, mix 1 tbsp red chili powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp garam masala, 1 tbsp lemon juice, 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste, and salt.
 3. Rub the spice mixture evenly over the fish pieces and marinate for at least 30 minutes.
 4. Heat oil in a frying pan over medium flame.
 5. Once hot, gently place the marinated fish pieces into the oil.
 6. Fry each side for 3–4 minutes or until golden brown and crispy.
 7. Remove and place on paper towels to drain excess oil.
 8. Serve hot with lemon wedges and sliced onions.

1. Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan and add 1 tsp mustard seeds, 1 chopped onion, and curry leaves. Sauté until golden brown.
 2. Add 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste and fry for a minute.
 3. Add 500g chicken pieces and cook until the color changes.
 4. Add 1 tsp turmeric, 1 tbsp red chili powder, 1 tsp coriander powder, and salt. Mix well.
 5. Cook covered on low heat until the chicken is tender (add a splash of water if needed).
 6. Meanwhile, dry roast 2 tbsp grated coconut, 1 tsp fennel seeds, 1 tsp cumin, and a few black peppercorns. Grind into a coarse paste.
 7. Add the coconut masala to the chicken and cook until dry and aromatic.
 8. Garnish with chopped coriander and serve hot with rice or chapati.

1. Clean and make deep cuts on 500g chicken pieces.
 2. In a bowl, mix 1 cup yogurt, 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste, 1 tbsp lemon juice, 1 tsp turmeric, 1 tbsp red chili powder, 1 tsp garam masala, and salt.
 3. Rub the marinade all over the chicken, making sure it seeps into the cuts.
 4. Cover and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight for best results.
 5. Preheat oven to 200°C (or prepare a grill/pan).
 6. Bake or grill the chicken for 25–30 minutes, turning halfway through, until charred and cooked through.
 7. Baste occasionally with butter or oil for extra flavor and moisture.
 8. Serve hot with lemon wedges and onion rings.

1. Soak 2 cups basmati rice for 30 minutes, then boil until 70% cooked. Drain and set aside.
 2. Marinate 500g chicken with 1 cup yogurt, 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste, 1 tsp red chili powder, 1 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp garam masala, salt, and lemon juice. Let it rest for 1 hour.
 3. In a large pan, heat oil and fry sliced onions until golden brown. Remove half for garnishing.
 4. Add whole spices (bay leaf, cinnamon, cloves, cardamom) and sauté.
 5. Add the marinated chicken and cook until tender and oil separates.
 6. Layer partially cooked rice over the chicken, sprinkle fried onions, mint, coriander, and a few saffron strands soaked in milk.
 7. Cover tightly with a lid or dough and cook on low heat (dum) for 20–25 minutes.
 8. Gently mix before serving hot with raita or salad.

1. Heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan and sauté 2 finely chopped onions until golden brown.
 2. Add 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste and cook until the raw smell disappears.
 3. Add 2 chopped tomatoes and cook until soft.
 4. Add 1 tsp red chili powder, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp coriander powder, and salt to taste. Cook the masala well.
 5. Add 500g cleaned chicken pieces and stir to coat with the masala.
 6. Cover and cook for 10–15 minutes until chicken is tender.
 7. Add 1/2 cup water (or as needed for gravy consistency) and simmer for another 10 minutes.
 8. Sprinkle garam masala and fresh coriander leaves before serving hot with rice or roti.
